metadata.name: You Can't Smooth A Crumpled Paper Or A Wrinkled Heart
metadata.description:
Black don’t crack, no, it don’t.  
But our skin belies  
Our wrinkled hearts  
Broken by slavery  
Trampled by Jim Crow  
Mocked and tested by…the now.  
Each wound, each injustice, each injury, each cut  
Becoming a new Middle Passage that 
America creates for us  
Paved with 
Words,  
Laws,  
Nooses,  
Guns.  
Four hundred and three years  
Is an imprint on our DNA.  
We cry secret tears,  
Under the cool glow of a soothing moon  
And at dawn  
We lift wrinkled hearts to the sun for healing,  
While we show beautiful shades  
Of smooth unbothered shea butter skin  
To the world.  
 
a poem by Leia
